facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 245 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 245 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 31, 1962 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal No. 563 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 31, 1962 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal No. 563 of 1959.

facts.text: High Court confirmed decree passed by Subordinate Judge at Eluru in O.S. No. 112 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: from a judgment and decree of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh confirming the decree passed by the Subordinate Judge at Eluru in O.S. No. 112 of 1955.

facts.text: Testatrix Boddu Adilakshmi was childless and brought up defendants 4 and 5 from infancy.

anchor.surface_text: The testatrix, Adilakshmi, who was childless herself brought up defendants 4 and 5, Boddu Ramarao and Kosury Lakshmamma, from their infancy.

facts.text: Will executed by Adilakshmi on June 28, 1913.

anchor.surface_text: At the date of the will executed on June 28, 1913 the girl defendant 5 had been with her for 15 years and the boy defendant 4 for 10 years

facts.text: At date of will, defendant 5 had been with testatrix for 15 years, defendant 4 for 10 years, both minors.

anchor.surface_text: At the date of the will executed on June 28, 1913 the girl defendant 5 had been with her for 15 years and the boy defendant 4 for 10 years and both were minors at the time.

facts.text: Will bequeathed all properties movable and immovable to defendants 4 and 5 after testatrix's lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: In order to provide for them after her death she executed a will bequeathing all her properties, movable and immovable.

facts.text: Will terms: property to pass to both minors Lakshmamma and Ramarao after lifetime, guardian Banda Ramaswamy Garu until majority, then possession to both, enjoy for life without gift/transfer/sale, after death children enjoy with powers.

anchor.surface_text: The translation of the relevant portion of the will which was in vernacular is as follows -- my entire property should hereafter my lifetime pass to. both these minors, Lakshmamma and Ramarao, that until their minority period is over, Banda Ramaswamy Garu should act as their guardian and deal with all the affairs, that after their minority period is over the entire property should be in possession of both of them, that both of them should enjoy throughout their lifetime the said property without powers of gift transfer and sale and that after their death the children that may be born to them should enjoy the same with powers of gift, transfer and sale.

facts.text: Testatrix died within a few days after execution of the will.

anchor.surface_text: The testatrix died within a few days after the execution of the will.

facts.text: Defendants 4 and 5 divided properties by registered partition deed dated December 27, 1929; Schedule A to 4th defendant, Schedule B to 5th defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 4 and 5 divided the properties left by the testatrix by a registered partition deed dated December 27, 1929 by which those mentioned in Schedule A to the plaint fell to the share of the 4th defendant while the others mentioned in Schedule B fell to the share of the 5th defendant.

facts.text: 4th defendant married 1st defendant Boddu Satyavathi, daughter of 5th defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The 4th defendant married the 1st defendant, Boddu Satyavathi who is the daughter of the 5th defendant.

facts.text: 2nd defendant is daughter born from marriage of 4th defendant and 1st defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd defendant is the daughter born out of this wedlock.

facts.text: 4th defendant later married Boddu Manikyam; plaintiffs 1 to 4 are issues of that marriage.

anchor.surface_text: Some years thereafter, the 4th defendant married one Boddu Manikyam. the plaintiffs 1 to 4 being the issues of the marriage of the 4th defendant with her.

facts.text: 5th defendant and 1st defendant mortgaged B schedule properties to 3rd defendant, who brought suit and obtained decree.

anchor.surface_text: The 5th defendant and the 1st defendant mortgaged the B schedule properties with the 3rd defendant who brought a suit on the mortgage and obtained a decree.

facts.text: Plaintiffs filed suit in 1955 against all defendants for declaration that after death of defendants 4 and 5, 1st defendant and children of 4th defendant entitled to share equally, alienations not binding beyond lifetime, mortgage decree not binding on plaintiffs or reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs filed the suit against all the defendants in 1955. for a declaration that after the death praying of defendants 4-and 5, the 1st defendant and the children of the 4th defendant or such of them as may be alive at the time would be entitled to share the properties in suit equally between them and that any alienation made by defendants 4 and 5 or their assignees or alienees would number bind the interests of the ultimate feversloners beyond their lifetime and further that the mortgage decree mentioned above was number binding on the plaintiffs or the ultimate reversioners.

facts.text: Trial court held defendants 4 and 5 holders of life estate, succeeded as tenants in common.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court came to the conclusion that defendants 4 and 5 were only the holders of life estate and that they had succeeded to the estate of Adilakshmi as tenants in common.

facts.text: High Court held life estate to 4 and 5, absolute estate to their children, vested remainder per stirpes not per capita.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the right of the children of defendants 4 and 5 to step into the shoes of the parents has been expressly mentioned in the instrument. The residuary estate has been given to the children. that may be bor n to the legatees who. it is provided, should enjoy the properties with powers of gift. transfer and sale. A life estate has been given to defendants 4 and 5 and an absolute estate to their children. ... The ultimate conclusion of the High Court was the bequest in favour of defendants 4 and 5 was that of a life estate with a vested remainder in favour of their children and that the children should take the vested remainder per stripes and number per capita.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with High Court conclusion that defendants 4 and 5 took as tenants in common with life estate.

anchor.surface_text: In our view. the High Court came to the correct conclusion.

facts.text: Partition of properties by defendants 4 and 5 indicates they were tenants in common.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further held that the conduct of the defendants in partitioning the properties went to fortify the above conclusion.

facts.text: Appellants contended that children of defendants 4 and 5 take per capita.

anchor.surface_text: On a fair construction of the language. it is difficult to accede to the contention of the appellants that the children of defendants 4 and 5 who may be actually alive at the time of the death of defendants 4 and 5, would take the properties per capita.

facts.text: Supreme Court held testatrix intended no power of sale or alienation for foster children, properties for their children.

anchor.surface_text: Before examining the principles of law involved, we may consider the intention of the testatrix in giving her properties to defendants 4 ,red 5. She brought them up like her own children but she did number want them to have the power of sale or alienation and desired that the properties be preserved for the benefit of their children.

facts.text: Foster children were minors at date of will.

anchor.surface_text: At the date of the will executed on June 28, 1913 the girl defendant 5 had been with her for 15 years and the boy defendant 4 for 10 years and both were minors at the time.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no intention for joint tenancy, as unknown to Hindu law except coparcenary.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that from this one can spell out a joint tenancy which is unknown to Hindu law except as above stated. The testatrix did number expressly mention that on the death of one all the properties would pass to the other by right of survivorship. We have numberdoubt on a construction of the will that the testatrix never intended the foster children to take the property as joint tenants.

facts.text: Foster children partitioned property in exercise of right as tenants in common.

anchor.surface_text: The foster children who became tenants in common partitioned the property in exercise of their right.

facts.text: Suit filed as O.S. No. 112 of 1955 by Subordinate Judge at Eluru.

anchor.surface_text: confirming the decree passed by the Subordinate Judge at Eluru in O.S. No. 112 of 1955.

arguments.claim: High Court came to correct conclusion on life estate to 4 and 5 as tenants in common with vested remainder per stirpes

anchor.surface_text: In our view. the High Court came to the correct conclusion.

arguments.claim: Testatrix brought up foster children like own but did not want them to have power of sale or alienation; desired properties preserved for benefit of their children

anchor.surface_text: Before examining the principles of law involved, we may consider the intention of the testatrix in giving her properties to defendants 4 ,red 5. She brought them up like her own children but she did number want them to have the power of sale or alienation and desired that the properties be preserved for the benefit of their children.

arguments.claim: Reasonable for testatrix to provide foster children enjoy income for lives, their children inherit as full owners; each get half income for life, children succeed to respective shares

anchor.surface_text: would be reasonable therefore for her to make provision in such way that the foster children would enjoy the income of the properties for their lives and that their children should inherit the Ip.C. l68 111 properties as full owners on the death of their parents. The donees of the life estate were minors at the date of the will and there was numberknowing when they would get married and how many children each would have. It would therefore be reason able to expect that the testatrix would so arrange her affairs that each of the foster children should get half of the income of the property for life and that their children should succeed to the respective interest of their parents.

arguments.claim: Principle of joint tenancy unknown to Hindu law except coparcenary; not right to import technical English conveyancing rule into construction of Hindu will

anchor.surface_text: The principle of joint tenancy appears to be unknown to Hindu law. except in the case of companyarcenary between the members of an undivided family. and that it was number right to import into the companystruction of a Hindu will an extremely technical rule of English companyveyancing.

arguments.claim: Jogeswar Narain Deo v. Ram Chand Dutt held joint tenancy unknown to Hindu law except coparcenary, no import English rules to Hindu will

anchor.surface_text: As early as 1896 it was held by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Jogeswar Narain Deo v. Ram Chand Dutt others 1  that The principle of joint tenancy appears to be unknown to Hindu law. except in the case of companyarcenary between the members of an undivided family. and that it was number right to import into the companystruction of a Hindu will an extremely technical rule of English companyveyancing.

arguments.claim: Principle reiterated in Babu Rani v. Rajendra Baksh Singh

anchor.surface_text: Many years later the principle was reiterated in the case of Babu Rani v. Rajendra Baksh Singh 2 .

arguments.claim: Indications in will that foster children take as joint tenants: entire property in possession of both, both enjoy for lifetime, after their death children born to them enjoy

anchor.surface_text: It was argued before us that there were indications in the will that the intention of the testatrix was that the foster children should take as joint tenants and that this was apparent from the clause in the will which provided that the entire property should be in possession of both of them and that both of them should enjoy throughout their lifetime the said property and that after their death the children that may be born to them should enjoy the same

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that their children should inherit the Ip.C. l68 111 properties as full owners on the death of their parents. The donees of the life estate

arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot spell out joint tenancy from this; unknown to Hindu law; no express survivorship clause

arguments.claim: Testatrix never intended foster children to take as joint tenants

anchor.surface_text: We have numberdoubt on a construction of the will that the testatrix never intended the foster children to take the property as joint tenants.

arguments.claim: Foster children partitioned property as tenants in common in exercise of their right

anchor.surface_text: The foster children who became tenants in common partitioned the property in exercise of their right.

arguments.claim: Foster children had life interest with vested remainder to their children, so latter take per stirpes not per capita

anchor.surface_text: As by the will the foster children were to have a life interest with a vested remainder to their children, the latter companyld only take per stirpes and number per capita.

arguments.claim: Halsbury and cases like Hutchinson's Trusts, Errington support per stirpes where gift to parents for life then to their children after respective deaths

anchor.surface_text: As Halsbury points out Volume 39--Third Edition at page 1106, Art. 1638 that a stirpital distribution would be adopted where the gift was to a number of parents and their children in such a manner that the children were substituted for, or took on the death of, their respective parents... The rule... Where a testator gives the income of his estate to two people, A. and B., for their lives and follows that gift by a direction that at their death, or at their deaths, or at or after the death or deaths of A. and B. the property is to go to their issue... companystrues it as a gift, to take effect on the death of each, of the share... to the issue of the deceased.

holdings.text: The High Court came to the correct conclusion that the bequest to defendants 4 and 5 was a life estate as tenants in common with vested remainder to their children per stirpes not per capita.

anchor.surface_text: In our view. the High Court came to the correct conclusion. Before examining the principles of law involved, we may consider the intention of the testatrix in giving her properties to defendants 4 ,red 5. She brought them up like her own children but she did number want them to have the power of sale or alienation and desired that the properties be preserved for the benefit of their children.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement with High Court's construction of will language, conduct of parties in partitioning, and rejection of per capita claim.

holdings.text: The testatrix did not want defendants 4 and 5 to have power of sale or alienation and desired properties preserved for benefit of their children.

anchor.surface_text: Before examining the principles of law involved, we may consider the intention of the testatrix in giving her properties to defendants 4 ,red 5. She brought them up like her own children but she did number want them to have the power of sale or alienation and desired that the properties be preserved for the benefit of their children.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inferred from will terms limiting enjoyment to lifetime without alienation powers and providing for children after death.

holdings.text: Principle of joint tenancy is unknown to Hindu law except in case of coparcenary and it is not right to import technical English conveyancing rules into construction of Hindu will.

anchor.surface_text: The principle of joint tenancy appears to be unknown to Hindu law. except in the case of coparcenary between the members of an undivided family. and that it was number right to import into the construction of a Hindu will an extremely technical rule of English conveyancing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Privy Council precedents in Jogeswar Narain Deo and Babu Rani.

holdings.text: Testatrix never intended foster children to take property as joint tenants.

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt on a construction of the will that the testatrix never intended the foster children to take the property as joint tenants. The foster children who became tenants in common partitioned the property in exercise of their right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express mention of survivorship; language does not spell out joint tenancy; inconsistent with Hindu law.

holdings.text: Foster children became tenants in common and partitioned the property in exercise of their right.

anchor.surface_text: The foster children who became tenants in common partitioned the property in exercise of their right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conduct of partitioning fortifies conclusion of tenancy in common.

holdings.text: Foster children had life interest with vested remainder to their children who take per stirpes and not per capita.

anchor.surface_text: As by the will the foster children were to have a life interest with a vested remainder to their children, the latter could only take per stirpes and not per capita. As Halsbury points out Volume 39--Third Edition at page 1106, Art. 1638 that a stirpital distribution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will structure substitutes children for parents' shares; supported by Halsbury and English cases like Hutchinson's Trusts and Errington.

holdings.text: Bequest in favour of defendants 4 and 5 was that of a life estate with a vested remainder in favour of their children.

anchor.surface_text: the ultimate conclusion of the High Court was the bequest in favour of defendants 4 and 5 was that of a life estate with a vested remainder in favour of their children and that the children should take the vested remainder per stirpes and not per capita.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express will terms: enjoy for lifetime without alienation, then children with full powers.

anchor.surface_text: In re Hutchinsons Trusts 1

precedents.cited_proposition: words 'after the decease of the said F.H.S. and R.S.' mean after their respective deaths
precedents.cited_holding: the words after the decease of the said Francis Hutchinson Synge and his brother Robert Synge mean after their respective deaths, or after the decease of each of them

precedents.citation: Errington, In re. Gibbs v. Lassam 1

anchor.surface_text: Errington, In re. Gibbs v. Lassam 1

precedents.cited_proposition: where gift to A and B for life then to their issue at their death(s), construed as to issue of each on death of each
precedents.cited_holding: Where a testator gives the income of his estate to two people, A. and B., for their lives and follows that gift by a direction that at their death, or at their deaths, or at or after the death or deaths of A. and B. the property is to go to their issue, the Court construes it as a gift, to take effect on the death of each, of the share to the income of which the deceased was entitled, to the issue of the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: In our view. the High Court came to the correct conclusion.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court held correct that defendants 4 and 5 have life estate as tenants in common with vested remainder to children per stirpes not per capita; appellants' contention rejected
